parts: Name this wooden submarine built by David Bushnell that failed to sink the HMS Eagle in 1776.
The Turtle attempted to sink the HMS Eagle in the harbor of this city, which had been abandoned by the Continental Army after the Battle of Brooklyn Heights
During the British Occupation, New York City was commanded by this general. He resigned after the failure of Burgoyne's expedition in 1777 and was replaced by George Clinton

answers: animals [accept obvious similar words like creatures, prompt on sentient beings or similar words; prompt on pets]
parts: Name these entities whose use as entertainment have been cited as forms of their abuse by philosophers like Tom Regan and Gary Francione.
This Australian philosopher at Princeton University is a major animal rights activist and has popularized the term “speciesism” in his 1975 book - Animal Liberation.

Singer identifies with the “hedonistic” branch of this philosophy developed by Jeremy Bentham which holds a “fundamental axiom” in ensuring the “greatest happiness of the greatest number” of individuals.

answers: The Tablet of Destinies [or Tablets of Destiny, or dub namtarra, or ṭup šīmātu, or ṭuppi šīmāti]
parts: Name this Mesopotamian deity who became king of the gods after defeating a dragon who personified the salty waters, named Tiamat, as described in the Enuma Elish.
Marduk was the chief god of this city and was honored during processions through its Ishtar Gate.
Marduk establishes himself as king by taking this item from Kingu, the leader of Tiamat’s armies. In other Mesopotamian tales, Ninurta reclaims this object by defeating the Anzu Bird.

answers: Joseph-Louis Lagrange [accept Euler-Lagrange equation; accept Lagrangian]
parts: Name this problem in which one seeks to find the curve of fastest descent for a sliding bead moving without friction in a vertical plane. The solution to this problem is a cycloid.

Bernoulli’s solution instead envisioned the falling bead as a ray of light and applied this law of refraction, which relates the ratio of the sines of the angles of incidence to the speed of light in different media.

The modern solution to the brachistochrone problem uses an equation from the calculus of variations named for Euler and this man. In classical mechanics, that equation is used to find paths where the time integral of this man’s namesake quantity is stationary.

Name this Italian composer, known for his 26 orchestral variations on La follia di Spagna and many successful operas like Armida. He apocryphally had a rivalry with a more famous contemporary in late 18th-century Vienna.

This contemporary of Salieri was actually not his rival, despite the poisoning rumor that spread after this child prodigy's early death. He produced works such as the Jupiter Symphony and Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.

This student of Salieri, an Austrian virtuoso pianist, had also been taught by Mozart as a child. He succeeded Haydn as music director at the Esterházy estate and, like Haydn, wrote a trumpet concerto for Anton Weidinger.

answers: husbands of The Wife of Bath [prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these characters. In the prologue of one work, two of these characters are described as bad while the other three are described as good.
The Wife of Bath appears in this collection of twenty-four stories by Geoffrey Chaucer, which includes characters like the Host and the Knight.
In The Canterbury Tales, this big-boned character is frequently drunk and enjoys heaving doors off hinges. In this character’s tale, Absolon is tricked into kissing Alisoun’s behind.

answers: self-cleaning glass [accept reasonable equivalents such as “glass that cleans itself”]

water splitting [accept oxygen evolution; accept logical equivalents such as “breaking the bonds of water”; accept a description of “forming oxygen and hydrogen gases from water” and prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this property of glass such as Pilkington Activ that rely on a thin coating of superhydrophilic titanium dioxide to photochemically break down organic matter and drastically reduce contact angle leading to slip off.

Titanium dioxide efficiently catalyzes this process according to the Honda–Fujishima effect, which makes it popular for self-cleaning glass. This process is easily done via breaking of O-H bonds through electrolysis.
The realization of the Honda–Fujishima effect for non-UV light was done using a co-catalyst of this metal, with symbol Cu.
Name this type of structure whose existence is justified by the saying “good fences make good neighbors”.
This author of the poem “Mending Wall” also wrote about two roads that diverge in a yellow wood in the poem “The Road Not Taken”.

In “Mending Wall,” the speaker notes that the wall is not useful since these animals are not present. Frost also described one of these animals who thinks “no more of wall-builders than fools” in a poem titled for one of these animals “in Apple Time”.

answers: Samoa [accept American Samoa or Samoan people]
parts: The “American” part of this group of islands in the Pacific Ocean is named for a Polynesian people. The Treaty of Cession of Tutuila, surrendering control of the territory, was signed in its capital Pago Pago.
This island, the largest in the Mariana Island Chain, was ceded to the US immediately following the Spanish-American War. The indigenous peoples on this island are called Chamorros.
This territory was sold to the US by Denmark in 1917 due to fears of it being seized and used as a German naval base. Its three main islands are St. Croix, St. Thomas, and St. John.

answers: inverse relationship [accept negative correlation or negatively correlated; accept descriptions like “as one increases, the other decreases”]
parts: Name this cost of borrowing set by the lender.
Interest rates greatly impact savings and investment, such as corporate or government-issued bonds. Give the type of relationship between bond prices and interest rates.
The real interest rate and nominal interest rates will differ due to inflation. This equation expresses the nominal interest rate as the sum of the real interest rate and expected inflation.

answers: doors [accept but DO NOT REVEAL doors to the Florence Baptistry; prompt on Gates of Paradise with “What general type of feature is that work?”]
Orsanmichele (“ohr-sahn-mee-KEH-lay”) [accept the Kitchen Garden of St. Michael]
parts: Name these features, another one of which was fashioned by Lorenzo Ghiberti after the Arte di Calimala judged that his sculpture of the Sacrifice of Isaac was better than Filippo Brunelleschi’s.
Ghiberti’s Gates of Paradise are found in the Baptistry of this Italian city. Brunelleschi ended up designing the dome of a notable cathedral found in this capital of Tuscany.
Ghiberti also sculpted an image of St. John the Baptist for this Florentine church. Other works in its fourteen exterior niches include Donatello’s St. Mark and Nanni di Banco’s Four Crowned Martyrs.

answers: Perón [accept Juan Perón; accept Isabel Perón]
Argentine Anticommunist Alliance [or Alianza Anticomunista Argentina; accept Triple A]
Dirty War [or Guerra sucia; accept Época de los desaparecidos]
parts: Give this surname. Supporters of a general with this surname were killed in the Ezeiza Massacre after he returned to Buenos Aires after an 18-year exile.
This far-right death squad under the leadership of Jose Lopez Rega was active under Isabel Perón’s rule. Despite its name, it targeted all government opponents, not just ones of a certain ideology.

The United States supported Operation Condor during this period of state terrorism in Argentina. During this period, right-wing death squads, including the Triple A, disappeared thousands of the Montoneros and other political opponents.

answers: pufferfish [or puffers, or Tetraodontidae; prompt on fish or pisces]
parts: Give these creatures whose name originates from Haitian folklore, in which malevolent sorcerers known as bokors may seek to create them.
While zombies play no role in the standard practice of this Haitian religion, they nonetheless are popularly associated with it. Temples in this religion are run by houngans and mambos.
In most accounts of zombification from Haiti, such as that of Clarivius Narcisse (“nahr-SEES”), living people are “zombified” using poison taken from these animals.

answers: cyanobacteria [or blue-green algae; do NOT accept or prompt on “algae”]
parts: Name this red planet. The Curiosity rover was sent to this planet to determine its habitability.

Another method for making Mars habitable utilizes Vika (“VEE-kuh”) generators which can be used to create oxygen using this ion. The presence of this ion in the toxic Martian soil was confirmed by Curiosity.

NASA has theorized the introduction of an ecopoiesis machine to establish a natural ecosystem on Mars. The machine employs this phylum of photosynthetic bacteria which caused the Great Oxygenation Event.

answers: the Father [accept but do not reveal the father of Six Characters in Search of an Author]
Six Characters in Search of an Author [or Sei personaggi in cerca d'autore]
parts: Name this husband of Amalia who takes his stepdaughter home after meeting her in a brothel.
That father appears in this play, which ends with the Director exclaiming that “I’ve lost a whole day over [the title group]” after a mute boy shoots himself with a revolver.
This Italian playwright wrote Six Characters in Search of an Author.

answers: Blackbeard [or Edward Teach; or Edward Thatch]
parts: Name this Jamaican city that was a haven for pirates until order was restored by Lieutenant Governor Henry Morgan. It fell from prominence after being devastated by a 1692 earthquake.

This captain of the Queen Anne’s Revenge reportedly put lit fuses under his hat before going into battle. This pirate was killed by Robert Maynard in 1718, and had earlier blockaded the port of Charles Town.
Among the pirates who were active after the end of the Golden Age was this French privateer, who established the colony of Campeche on Galveston Island.

answers: R-naught [or R-sub-zero; accept basic reproduction number or ratio; prompt on partial answer]
infection [or infected; accept force of infection]
parts: Name this quantity, the dominant eigenvalue for the next generation matrix. It is equal to the ratio of transmission rate beta and recovery rate gamma in the SIR model.

A flow from the S to I compartment is defined as the parameter lambda or the “force” of this process. The second differential equation in the SIR model defines this process and “recovered” individuals are no longer susceptible to this process.
The aforementioned SIR model describes these events, which rely on the value of R-naught for their stability, like the ongoing one caused by COVID-19.

This character escapes execution by betraying his fellow prisoner Gonzalo and later marries Gonzalo’s sister Catalina. This newspaper tycoon reflects on his sordid life while on his deathbed in a novel by Carlos Fuentes.

This title character of another Fuentes work is killed by the general Tomas Arroyo after he attempts to burn a set of documents. Later in the novel, this character’s corpse is unearthed and “executed” by firing squad.
Juvencio cries “Tell them not to kill me!” while facing execution for the murder of Don Lupe in a short story by this other Mexican author, which is found in his collection The Burning Plain.
Name these objects which are clenched in the teeth of a skeleton in a dark work by Vincent van Gogh.
This work by Paul Serusier, which depicts the reflection of trees over the Aven River, was painted on the back of a cigar box and led to the formation of the group Les Nabis.
Richard Prince pioneered Appropriation art by rephotographing Marlboro ads but has since moved on to stealing images from this social media platform that is primarily used for sharing photos.

answers: Kingdom of Bavaria [or Königreich Bayern; or Kinereich Bayern]
parts: Name this Wagner-obsessed king who built the Neuschwanstein Castle.
Ludwig II ruled this kingdom in Southern Germany from Munich.
Riots broke out in Bavaria in 1844 after Ludwig I imposed a tax on this good. The 1516 Reinheitsgebot law imposed standards of purity for this good produced in Bavaria.
